oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Valley of the Macaws
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Williamson, Sheri
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: We've all heard that "every picturetells a story" and "one picture is worth athousand words:' But the story a picturetells and the one behind it may be verydifferent, and that hidden story may beone only words can tell. Take, forexample, these photographs of militarymacaws taken in eastern Mexico by mynaturalist-husband Tom Wood. They tellmuch about the appearance andbehavior of these birds. The color anddetails of the plumage, the separation ofpairs within the flying flock, and theirway of dealing with the clusters of soapberrieson which they are feeding canbe easily seen. One can also infer thatwe are lucky to get so close to one of theNew World's most spectacular psittacines.What the viewer can't see orinfer is the clash of cultures which madethese photos possible and perhapssaved a macaw's life.
